text: And as for Ishmael, I have heard thee: Behold, I have blessed him, and will make him fruitful, and will multiply him exceedingly ; twelve  princes shall he beget, and I will make him a great nation.
text_kjv: And as for Ishmael, I have heard thee: Behold, I have blessed him, and will make him fruitful, and will multiply him exceedingly ; twelve  princes shall he beget, and I will make him a great nation.
text_niv: And as for Ishmael, I have heard you: I will surely bless him; I will make him fruitful and will greatly increase his numbers. He will be the father of twelve rulers, and I will make him into a great nation.
text_esv: As for Ishmael, I have heard you; behold, I have blessed him and will make him fruitful and multiply him greatly. He shall father twelve princes, and I will make him into a great nation.
text_nlt: As for Ishmael, I will bless him also, just as you have asked. I will make him extremely fruitful and multiply his descendants. He will become the father of twelve princes, and I will make him a great nation.
text_msg: "And Ishmael? Yes, I heard your prayer for him. I'll also bless him; I'll make sure he has plenty of children—a huge family. He'll father twelve princes; I'll make him a great nation.
text_nasb: 'As for Ishmael, I have heard you; behold, I will bless him, and will make him fruitful and will multiply him exceedingly. He shall become the father of twelve princes, and I will make him a great nation.
context: Genesis 17 provides crucial insight into the covenant God establishes with Abraham, previously known as Abram. Abram, by this point, is 99 years old and Sarai is 90. God’s promise of countless descendants has remained unfulfilled, leading to Abram and Sarai taking matters into their own hands through Hagar, Sarai's Egyptian maidservant, resulting in the birth of Ishmael. The historical context is rooted in ancient Near Eastern customs where barrenness was considered a great shame and secondary wives or concubines were often used to secure an heir. God's intervention at this stage highlights his sovereignty and determination to fulfill his promise despite human attempts to manipulate the situation. God changes Abram's name to Abraham, signifying 'father of a multitude,' and Sarai's name to Sarah, signifying 'princess,' marking a new phase in their relationship with Him. Circumcision is instituted as a sign of the covenant, a physical symbol of their commitment to God. God explicitly promises a son, Isaac, through Sarah, with whom He will establish His everlasting covenant. Ishmael is already 13 years old at this time. Considering the immense importance placed on lineage and inheritance in ancient cultures, Abraham's concern for Ishmael's future is understandable. His plea for God to bless Ishmael reflects a father's love and responsibility for his son's well-being, even as God reiterates His specific plan for Isaac. The verse concerning Ishmael is a direct response to Abraham's plea, revealing God's compassionate nature and willingness to bless even those outside the primary covenant line.
meaning: This verse holds significant theological weight because it showcases God's grace and impartiality. While God's covenant is specifically established with Isaac and his descendants, He also demonstrates care and provision for Ishmael. This reveals a crucial aspect of God's character: He is not limited in His blessings. Although Ishmael will not inherit the covenant promises associated with the lineage of Isaac leading to the Messiah, he is nonetheless blessed and destined for greatness in his own right. The promise of becoming a 'great nation' and fathering 'twelve princes' indicates a significant level of prosperity and power. This foreshadows the establishment of twelve tribes descended from Ishmael, mirroring the twelve tribes of Israel descended from Jacob (Israel), Isaac's son. This parallelism highlights God's ability to work out His purposes even through those not directly connected to the covenant line. It emphasizes that God's blessings extend beyond the chosen people, demonstrating His universal concern for all humanity. Theologically, this verse also reinforces the concept of divine sovereignty. God's plan unfolds according to His will, but He also acknowledges and responds to human concerns, as seen in His reassurance to Abraham regarding Ishmael. This interaction reveals a relationship between divine determination and human agency, where God's plan is not thwarted by human actions but rather incorporates them into His overall design. It serves as a testament to God's ability to redeem situations and provide blessings even in circumstances that seem to deviate from His original purpose.
application: In modern life, Genesis 17:20 offers profound lessons about inclusivity, grace, and the scope of God's blessings. First, it challenges us to broaden our understanding of God's love and concern. Often, we can become fixated on specific groups or ideologies, forgetting that God's grace extends to all people, regardless of their background, beliefs, or circumstances. This verse encourages us to practice radical empathy and compassion towards those who may be different from us, remembering that they, too, are recipients of God's care. It calls us to challenge our prejudices and biases, seeking to understand and appreciate the diversity of human experience. Secondly, it highlights the importance of recognizing and celebrating the unique contributions of individuals and communities outside our immediate circles. Just as Ishmael was promised greatness and a significant future, so too are countless individuals and groups around the world destined to make a positive impact. We must be willing to acknowledge their accomplishments, support their endeavors, and learn from their perspectives. This verse encourages us to foster collaboration and partnership across cultural and religious boundaries, recognizing that we can all benefit from each other's strengths. Thirdly, it underscores the power of prayer and the importance of bringing our concerns to God. Abraham's intercession for Ishmael demonstrates the efficacy of prayer in shaping the lives of others. We are called to pray not only for our own needs but also for the well-being of those around us, including those who may be marginalized or disadvantaged. This act of prayer can transform our hearts and motivate us to action, inspiring us to become agents of positive change in the world. Finally, it reminds us that God's plan is multifaceted and that His blessings can manifest in unexpected ways. We may not always understand God's purposes, but we can trust that He is working all things together for good. This verse encourages us to embrace uncertainty and to remain open to the possibility of God's blessings unfolding in ways that we never anticipated.
prayer: Heavenly Father, Your word teaches us that your love extends beyond the confines of our understanding, reaching to all people. Thank you for the promise you made to Abraham regarding Ishmael, a testament to your boundless grace. Help us to see the world through your eyes, recognizing the inherent worth and potential in every individual, regardless of their background or beliefs. Forgive us for the times we have limited your blessings, confined them within the narrow walls of our own prejudices. Open our hearts to embrace diversity, to celebrate the unique contributions of others, and to work towards a world where all are valued and respected. Grant us the wisdom to pray for those who are different from us, lifting them up in your light and seeking your blessings upon them. May we be instruments of your peace and love, reflecting your compassion to all we encounter. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: It means God has separate plans for both. Isaac's line carries the covenant promise of salvation, while Ishmael's line is blessed with worldly prosperity and numerous descendants. It shows God's justice and mercy towards all. Both lineages are important, but for different reasons.

faqs.answer: This verse demonstrates God's universal care. While the covenant is through Isaac, God also blesses Ishmael abundantly. This shows that God's favor isn't exclusively for one group but extends to blessing others outside that specific lineage.
